2.text:
Thank you all very much for the great privilege
it is to do this presentation tonight.

8.text:
Vice-Chancellor Peter Lee, Deputy Vice-Chancellor,
Research, Professor Geraldine Mackenzie, Dean

14.text:
Rocque Reynolds, Professor Bee-Chen Goh and,
of course the Honourable Michael Kirby AC

20.text:
CMG, Chairman Emeritus of the Australian Law
Reform Commission. Like Bee-Chen I would also

28.text:
like to pay my respects to the traditional
custodians of the land on which we are meeting

33.text:
this evening, and respectfully acknowledgment
elders past and present, and I liked, Bee

39.text:
Chen, your addition of emerging leaders (elders)
I think that is a beautiful addition to the

44.text:
acknowledgment that is not only customary
but important.

51.text:
The topic of my talk this evening - I was
speaking last Saturday night to my parents.

60.text:
On Saturday nights they dine with me and my
husband, my very patient and long-suffering

67.text:
husband, Professor John Croucher. And I relieve
my mother of 70 years of making dinner for

73.text:
my father. And they are both 93 — and a
half. Almost a collective double century and

83.text:
they are both acute of mind, and almost of
body, although my mother is quite deaf these

90.text:
days. And my father was - we were just conversing
about the challenges and the things that were

97.text:
on my calendar for this week, and I mentioned
that I was doing the ‘Michael Kirby Lecture’.

102.text:
As I mentioned my mother is a little deaf,
she thought I was doing the ‘microsurgery

110.text:
lecture’. Entirely unruffled, though perhaps
a little curious, she assumed that it was

117.text:
normal fare for me to be doing a lecture on
such matters. Anyway, we all laughed when

123.text:
I gently corrected her as one does with one’s
aged mother and they both send their very

129.text:
warm greetings to the eponymous subject of
this evening’s presentation. They have known

136.text:
Mr Kirby for a very long time, although my
parents are decades older than Mr Kirby. And

143.text:
I will, in respect, address Mr Kirby as Mr
which was the appellation he requested that

150.text:
he be called in his wonderful retirement ceremony
from the High Court in 2009, although it's

156.text:
a bit like doctors, the most senior doctors
who become ‘Mr’ and eschew their doctoral

165.text:
titles.
The observation about microsurgery reminded

169.text:
me of a story, it's a legend, forgive me if
share it again with the group this evening.

175.text:
It was a lecture that Mr Kirby presented in
Zimbabwe — on breastfeeding, in the 1980s,

181.text:
as mischievously recounted by the late Roddy
Meagher, a fellow justice of the Court of

186.text:
Appeal in New South Wales. Justice Meagher,
Roddy Meagher, observed that perhaps due to

194.text:
differences in accent and the vagaries of
long-distance telephone communications, Mr

199.text:
Kirby had misheard the topic, and what was
supposed to be his lecture was a lecture on

204.text:
‘press freedom’. It was, in fact, an invited,
and very learned, address on ‘Bioethics,

214.text:
Breastmilk and Commonwealth Cooperation’.
The late Gordon Samuels, Court of Appeal colleague

221.text:
and later Governor of NSW, apparently said
to Mr Kirby on his return, ‘Kirby, is there

226.text:
nothing you will not speak about?’ But I
think what Michael Kirby has demonstrated,

232.text:
in his collected works, now up to many, many
volumes, is that there is nothing that he

238.text:
is unable to speak about.
In my presentation this evening I will begin

245.text:
with Michael Kirby’s vision for the Australian
Law Reform Commission and then to speak about

251.text:
human rights and the ALRC’s work. I then
turn to the idea of ‘re-imagining’ law

259.text:
reform—of seeing law reform through different
lenses. So much has already been written about

266.text:
law reform commissions, especially on pertinent
anniversaries, 25ths, 30ths. And the 50th

272.text:
of the UK, the Law Commission of England and
Wales is coming up now in fact tomorrow and

277.text:
Saturday we will be doing a similar sort of
event in the UK. But I thought I would use

283.text:
this year, the 40th anniversary of the Australian
Law Reform Commission, and the fact that Michael

290.text:
Kirby was the foundation Chairman, as a catalyst
for what I have described as ‘re-imagining’.

297.text:
I will do that this evening — to ‘look
through the looking-glass’ if I may, in

303.text:
different ways. And I’m going to present
this as a triptych, thus: Pebbles in a Pond,

311.text:
A Mannered Dance and Mille Fleurs. And I will
conclude with some reflections on the ALRC

319.text:
in the 21st century.
Michael’s vision for the ALRC.

326.text:
Michael Kirby’s life is threaded through
with a deep and abiding commitment to human

330.text:
rights. He also has a deep understanding of
people and the power of communication. He

337.text:
was a perfect fit as the foundation Chairman
of the ALRC, or ‘Law Reform Commission’

343.text:
as it was then called. No matter how serendipitous
may have been the now-legendary meeting of

349.text:
the then 35 year old Michael, in the lift
with the then Attorney-General, Senator the

354.text:
Hon Lionel Murphy, and the champagne-laced
discussion, that included Geoffrey Robertson,

361.text:
still with the accent of his youth, that cemented
it. I am very privileged to be the current

368.text:
incumbent of the position, or Mr Kirby’s
‘successor-in-title’ as he dubbed me.

374.text:
The role is now as ‘President’, rather
than ‘Chairman’, but its ethos and mission

379.text:
remains the same — and just about everything
at the ALRC bears the imprint of Michael Kirby’s

387.text:
vision.
In pride of place, as you enter our modest

392.text:
offices, there is a photograph of the initial
Commissioners. They were appointed by an instrument

398.text:
signed by the Governor General and Senator
Murphy, dated 31st of December 1974 — no

406.text:
office close-down between Christmas and New
Year, let alone for the Governor General in

410.text:
those days. In that photograph, seated at
the front, are Michael Kirby, on the cusp

416.text:
of 36 years of age, a bearded Gareth Evans,
then 30 years old, and then a Senior Lecturer

423.text:
at the University of Melbourne, and Associate
Professor Gordon Hawkins, the late Sydney

429.text:
University criminologist, nude sunbather and
star of 1960s daytime television. They are

437.text:
sitting on rather elegant velvet-covered Victorian
armchairs — Kirby’s red, the others green.

442.text:
Behind them stand Gerard Brennan QC as he
then was, 46, included, as Kirby commented,

449.text:
to ‘add weight and gravitas’ to the group,
the late Professor Alex Castles, 41, — legal

456.text:
historian par excellence, and John Cain, 43.
Mr Kirby was a dapper young man, in a double-breasted

464.text:
pinstripe suit, white handkerchief tucked
neatly in breast pocket, looking confidently

469.text:
at the camera. If you look more closely you
see the well-scuffed soles of his shoes and,

476.text:
although, possibly unawares, displaying a
little leg above his sock. These days no doubt

481.text:
it would be photoshopped out. There is a freshness,
innocence even, commitment, confidence and

488.text:
optimism in the faces that are captured in
that photograph. What an impressive line-up

494.text:
to begin the work of the newly constituted
Law Reform Commission.

500.text:
What was the blueprint that Kirby imprinted
on this embryonic law reform body? While he

508.text:
had the model of the Law Commission of England
and Wales as the forerunner and benchmark

512.text:
of the modern institutional law reform commission
to refer to, and the influence of great Lord

518.text:
Leslie Scarman, Kirby had virtually a blank
slate upon which to write: the power to do

525.text:
all things necessary or convenient to be done
for or in connection with the performance

530.text:
of the ALRC’s work.
His ‘brief’ was set out in the first Act,

536.text:
expressed in how the Commission was to perform
its functions. It was a ‘rights and liberties’

542.text:
focus: Section 7 of the Act said that the
Commission shall review laws to which the

549.text:
Act applies, and consider proposals, with
a view to ensuring that such laws and proposals

555.text:
do not trespass unduly on personal rights
and liberties, and do not unduly make the

561.text:
rights and liberties of citizens dependent
upon administrative rather than judicial decisions;

567.text:
and that, as far as practicable, such laws
and proposals are consistent with the Articles

572.text:
of the International Covenant on Civil and
Political Rights.

577.text:
The particular obligation expressed in that
provision was the result of an amendment by

585.text:
the opposition, Shadow Attorney-General, Senator
Ivor Greenwood QC. The fact that amendments

593.text:
like that and others were accepted, even welcomed,
by Senator Murphy as Attorney General, reflects

601.text:
the strong bipartisan support for the creation
of the ALRC. It was also the first reference

609.text:
in an Australian Act to the International
Covenant, the ICCPR (International Covenant

615.text:
on Civil and Political Rights), pre-dating
by a number of years the establishment of

619.text:
what is now known as the Australian Human
Rights Commission. Writing in 1976, Mr Kirby

626.text:
predicted that this obligation ‘may in time
become a provision of considerable importance’,

633.text:
extremely prescient.
So the ALRC was born with an eye to the impact

637.text:
of law and law reform on personal rights and
liberties. This brief has remained essentially

643.text:
the same today, although it’s generalised
to other international conventions as well.

650.text:
In speaking at the celebration of the first
25 years of the ALRC, Kirby remarked that

656.text:
international human rights law had at last
reached Australia in a practical way. In relation

664.text:
to the approach to law reform in practice,
Mr Kirby said, ‘ it was significantly different

672.text:
from overseas commissions. We took our proposals
to the general public to whom the law ultimately

678.text:
belongs. We used radio and television shamelessly.
This was very difficult’ he said ‘for

685.text:
a naturally shy person like me. Because our
methodology from the start was distinctively

691.text:
Australian, our approach was congenial to
a country of robust individualists’. His

696.text:
objective was to provide, through the processes
of consultation, an ‘institutional voice’

703.text:
for those beyond ‘the big end of town’,
particularly ‘the poor and the powerless’.

710.text:
In the introduction to the very large tome
written to mark Mr Kirby’s retirement from

715.text:
the High Court in 2009, Appealing to the Future
— Michael Kirby and His Legacy, Ian Freckelton

722.text:
said that ‘law reform Kirby-style was different’.
It was ‘more inclusive, more energetic and

731.text:
with a broader vision’. This was Kirby’s
blueprint: to consult, take the ideas to the

739.text:
public, and ensure that all the public was
included; and to develop recommendations for

745.text:
reform in accordance with international human
rights law.

750.text:
So, what about human rights and the ALRC?
We are a law reform commission, but a focus

760.text:
on rights and liberties was embedded in our
functions, in our statutory mandate. But it’s

768.text:
also, the idea of rights and liberties are
embedded in the interstices of the common

774.text:
law — long before the word human was added
to the description. And I thought that it

781.text:
might be appropriate to look at where the
ALRC might fit in, in this particular time

787.text:
of intense scrutiny on rights and liberties,
in the 800th anniversary year of the sealing

794.text:
of the Magna Carta of 1215.
So first a word about Magna Carta and rights

801.text:
as they are expressed in the common law. While
the Magna Carta, great charter has achieved

808.text:
somewhat iconic proportions, and the reality
of it is perhaps far more modest, its symbolism

815.text:
is undeniable. Nicholas Cowdery AM QC, Chair
of the Magna Carta Committee of the Rule of

822.text:
Law Institute of Australia, in speaking at
a special service at St James’ Church in

828.text:
Sydney on the 14th of June, said that the
significance of the Magna Carta ‘lies not

833.text:
so much in the text or any versions of it,
but the principles behind the text — the

840.text:
values and concepts that support it, the idea
of the Magna Carta itself’.

846.text:
And so the language of rights and liberties
has been carried along with the ‘idea’

852.text:
of Magna Carta over the centuries — and
well before the ‘human’ was added in the

857.text:
modern, post World War II context, to the
notion of rights and liberties. It is not

863.text:
surprising I think with the passage or acceptance
of the Universal Declaration of Human Rights

870.text:
in 1948 that it was described as a ‘declaration
that may well become the international Magna

878.text:
Carta for all men everywhere’ - that was
Eleanor Roosevelt. Many of the rights and

884.text:
liberties that are now enshrined in the conventions
and covenants of the international community

890.text:
of nations may be seen as creatures of the
common law evolving from Magna Carta. In a

896.text:
sense the international conventions themselves
captured, in a very formal way, the agreed

902.text:
set of fundamental rights and freedoms at
the time—and in the wake of the horrors

907.text:
of the global cataclysm of the times.
The Hon James Spigelman AC QC has become somewhat

914.text:
of a Magna Carta rock star this year with
excellent and erudite speeches on the subject.

920.text:
Spigelman says that ‘we can legitimately
trace the strength of our tradition of the

925.text:
rule of law to this document’. And the support
of liberties has developed in the wake of

931.text:
the demarcation between the great organs of
state. The Magna Carta, and its companion

936.text:
offspring, the Forest Charter, he said, ‘stand
in, and propagate, the tradition of organic

942.text:
legitimacy’. What we came to know as civil
liberties or, in earlier centuries as the

948.text:
‘rights of Englishmen’, were the practical
manifestations of experience of the law over

953.text:
the centuries as manifest in judicial decisions
and in legislation.

958.text:
Our common law, anchored as it is in English
constitutional history, is redolent with the

964.text:
principles that were born of Magna Carta and
its compact with the King. The protection

971.text:
of the ‘rights of Englishmen’ by the common
law became embodied in principles of statutory

977.text:
interpretation. As the Hon Robert French,
Chief Justice of the High Court remarked:

981.text:
‘many of the things we think of as basic
rights and freedoms come from the common law

986.text:
and how the common law is used to interpret
Acts of Parliament and regulations made under

992.text:
them so as to minimise intrusion into those
rights and freedoms’. But while intrusions

999.text:
should be minimised, the interpretation of
legislation by Courts is something that occurs

1005.text:
‘against the backdrop of Parliamentary supremacy’:
which can, ‘by using clear words’ the

1011.text:
Chief Justice said ‘for which it can be
held politically accountable, qualify or extinguish

1017.text:
those rights and freedoms except to the extent
that they may be protected by the Constitution.

1023.text:
Whether the words of parliament are clear
enough, is expressed in terms of the principle

1027.text:
of legality — a rule of statutory interpretation.
Which means that if Parliament ‘squarely

1034.text:
confronts’ the issue of intrusion upon rights,
and the intention is clear and unambiguous,

1039.text:
then the statute will be interpreted as having
its desired effect. Subject to the Constitution,

1045.text:
Parliament can modify or extinguish common
law rights. In other words, Parliament must

1051.text:
confront encroachment squarely, own it politically,
and defend it in legislative terms unambiguously.

1059.text:
And, I should add, or suffer the political
consequences: political accountability means

1065.text:
you can get voted out.
There are other ways of course of protecting

1070.text:
rights in law. Just because Australia does
not, at the federal level, have some formal

1076.text:
‘bill’ or ‘charter’ of rights, does
not mean that there is no respect for rights.

1082.text:
Indeed I would like to take it as a given,
that rights-mindedness informs much of the

1087.text:
actions of people in the community, even though
people differ in the answers they may give

1092.text:
to the same questions.
This is not the occasion for me to argue for

1097.text:
or against further entrenching into our constitutional
structure a bill or charter of rights. This

1102.text:
has been the subject of two excellent previous
addresses in the series of Kirby lectures.

1110.text:
But it is of great interest to me at the moment
because the idea of protecting rights from

1115.text:
encroachment is the centrepiece of the ALRC’s
work in this Magna Carta anniversary year.

1122.text:
Hard on the heels of completing an inquiry
on aspects of Native Title, we are in the

1127.text:
final stages of an inquiry that looks at encroachments
in Commonwealth laws on traditional rights,

1133.text:
freedoms and privileges, and whether such
encroachments are justified.

1138.text:
And I think, in the context of Australia,
without a statutory bill or charter of rights,

1145.text:
what is interesting to observe, what protections
there may be within our existing structure,

1151.text:
which is essentially a ‘political rights
review’ or ‘legislative rights review’

1157.text:
model. Through the processes of Parliament
itself and the actions of Government Departments

1163.text:
prior to the formulation of legislation, there
is intense scrutiny on legislation through

1170.text:
a rights lens. And indeed the procedural justificatory
processes extend way beyond Parliament as

1179.text:
well. Some of those processes include for
instance the statement of compatibility against

1186.text:
a whole list of International Conventions
that must accompany bills that go before the

1191.text:
House now, and there is a Joint Parliamentary
Committee on Human Rights that scrutinises

1196.text:
them. The Attorney-General’s Department
oversees the preparation of those statements

1202.text:
of compatibility and there are considerable
guides within the bureaucratic end of drafting

1207.text:
legislation where such matters are considered.
So it’s not silent as to rights, it just

1213.text:
justifies encroachments in a different way.
I should also mention, in terms of the after

1220.text:
legislation, apart from voting out, the Australian
Law Reform Commission routinely considers

1226.text:
rights and freedoms in our inquiries — and
especially in the current one. All our work

1232.text:
takes place within an obligation to consider
the impact of rights and liberties, with the

1237.text:
international conventions sitting on our collective
shoulders. A recent example of that is the

1244.text:
inquiry I led into Equality, Capacity and
Disability in Commonwealth Laws (ALRC Report

1250.text:
124, August 2014). We were asked to consider
‘how maximising individual autonomy and

1254.text:
independence could be modelled in Commonwealth
laws’. A centrepiece of the reform recommendations

1261.text:
that we developed was a set of National Decision-Making
Principles and a Commonwealth decision-making

1267.text:
model, reflecting the paradigm shift signalled
in the United Nations Convention of the Rights

1273.text:
of Persons with Disabilities, to recognise
people with disabilities as persons before

1278.text:
the law, and their right to make choices for
themselves.

1283.text:
Graeme Innes AM, who was then Disability Discrimination
Commissioner had a second ‘hat’ as Part-time

1289.text:
Commissioner of the Australian Law Reform
Commission and worked with me on that Inquiry

1293.text:
and described the report as ‘an internationally
groundbreaking examination of the implications

1300.text:
of the United Nations Convention for laws
and legal frameworks that might disempower

1305.text:
people with disability’. Graeme had a lovely
nickname for that convention he just called

1313.text:
it the ‘disco’.
But as part of the broader rights review processes

1318.text:
I should also mention the Australian Human
Rights Commission. Established in 1986, with

1324.text:
its predecessor in 1981 known as HREOC (Human
Rights and Equal Opportunity Commission) have

1327.text:
as their express purpose - working for the
progressive implementation of designated international

1333.text:
conventions and declarations through representations
to the Federal Parliament and the executive,

1338.text:
through other public awareness activities,
and where appropriate through intervention

1342.text:
in judicial proceedings.
No less importantly, laws are commonly scrutinised

1349.text:
by the public and in the press. So, there
is a lot of ‘justification’ going on:

1354.text:
questions being asked, challenges being put.
Rights-mindedness permeates the body politic.

1360.text:
But this doesn’t mean that Parliament necessarily
gets it ‘right’— the pragmatic is not

1365.text:
necessarily ‘pure’—and this is where
political accountability comes in—and the

1371.text:
work of bodies like the Australian Law Reform
Commission. Our work this year is infused

1377.text:
with consideration of rights in our wonderfully
wide Terms of Reference and also in our statutory

1383.text:
mandate.
In the next three sections I begin my reimagining

1390.text:
and as I said I will start my triptych with
the first, which is labelled Pebbles in a

1395.text:
Pond.
How do we know we are doing well? To justify

1401.text:
our existence over 40 years we must be doing
something ‘good’ if I can paraphrase sister

1407.text:
Maria in The Sound of Music.
‘Implementation’ data is one way – the

1414.text:
darling of those who like key performance
indicators. But it’s not all about statistics.

1421.text:
A lack of implementation, of itself, does
not mean failure. It’s not even a very good

1426.text:
guide to performance, although our statistics
over time are very good. I mentioned that

1432.text:
as of June 2014, over 88% of Australian Law
Reform Commission’s reports had been substantially

1439.text:
or partially implemented. But it’s not all
about statistics.

1443.text:
My personal conviction, after nearly nine
years at the ALRC, is that an assessment of

1448.text:
the contribution that law reform makes must
be seen through another lens. It is like a

1455.text:
pebble in a pond. There are ripples that run
over the surface of the pond — the extending,

1461.text:
echoing impact, long after the pebble has
disappeared beneath the surface of the water.

1468.text:
The ripples are multiple and overlapping.
Here are some...

1473.text:
Ripple one — the value of the reports
Here one must necessarily take a long view.

1481.text:
The assessment of the contribution in the
value of the reports must be seen in the light

1486.text:
of legal history. Because law reform publications
— especially the final reports — provide

1493.text:
an enormous contribution to legal history,
through the mapping of law at a particular

1499.text:
moment in time. When I was working on my own
doctorate, which was a legal historical one,

1506.text:
I found the reports of the UK Real Property
Commissioners of the 1830s, the most wonderful

1512.text:
resource. Each law reform commission report,
like those of the 1830s, maps its present

1520.text:
as well as its past. But what the ALRC does
in reports is also provide a snapshot of opinion

1528.text:
on the issues being considered, in weaving
in the comments and thoughts and contributions

1536.text:
we receive through consultations and through
submissions, which increasingly locates our

1542.text:
work within its particular social context
at a given time.

1546.text:
A good example of that particular ripple is
the inquiry undertaken by the ALRC into the

1553.text:
recognition of Aboriginal Customary Laws,
which was completed in 1986 — almost 30

1560.text:
years ago. That was a mammoth nine-year inquiry,
the ALRC’s 31st report — running to over

1568.text:
1,000 pages. It remains one of the most-viewed
reports on the ALRC website — it’s been

1577.text:
visited, and this is only since we started
counting in 2010, over 200,000 times. And

1584.text:
since 2010 it’s the 4th most downloaded
of all our reports — over 5,000 times, and

1594.text:
that’s just from our website alone.
This kind of interest, and especially in work

1599.text:
such as the Customary Laws report, continuing
now almost 3 decades after the report was

1605.text:
completed, signifies a dimension of importance
of our work and impact, even where specific

1612.text:
recommendations may not yet find their way
into specific legislative action. And, significantly,

1619.text:
the reflections in that report, we returned
to in the Native Title inquiry, which as I

1625.text:
mentioned was just completed. On the 29th
of June we launched the report, Connection

1631.text:
to Country: Review of the Native Title Act
1993 (Cth).

1636.text:
It’s not only law students, and I include
the students in the room this evening, It’s

1642.text:
not only law students who use ALRC reports
for their university assignments although

1646.text:
there is enormous traffic of that kind. As
Kirby observed in a contribution he wrote

1652.text:
for the 30th anniversary of the ALRC: ‘It
is beyond question that courts and academic

1659.text:
institutions are increasingly turning to law
reform reports as a significant, intensive

1666.text:
and accurate source of legal authority, principle
and policy. In this way, even if unimplemented

1673.text:
by the Parliament, a law reform report can
influence the development of the law by the

1679.text:
courts, and also by officials and other agencies.’
In support of such observations, I note here

1685.text:
the remarks of the Federal Court in 2010:
‘The Court benefits greatly from the ALRC’s

1691.text:
reports, research and analysis of complex
areas of law within federal jurisdiction.

1696.text:
More often than not, the report wrote an ALRC
report contains the best statement or source

1703.text:
of the current law on a complex and contentious
topic that can remain the case for decades

1709.text:
thereafter, whether or not the ALRC’s recommendations
are subsequently implemented. The ALRC’s

1716.text:
reports, in this way, have assisted the Court
in the tasks of ascertaining the law, interpreting

1722.text:
statute and developing the common law.
A recent example of that is from a decision

1729.text:
in Western Australia where that impact was
brought this home to me. It was the decision

1734.text:
of Justice Mitchell in Wilson v Ferguson [2015]
WASC 15. The case is a classic example of

1741.text:
what has become known — sadly — as ‘revenge
porn’, where private and sometimes explicit

1748.text:
photographs and videos taken in the course
of a romantic relationship are posted publicly

1754.text:
on the internet after the relationship has
broken down. The aggrieved party brought an

1760.text:
action for breach of confidence, seeking an
injunction and ‘damages’. Justice Mitchell

1767.text:
took issue with the last aspect of the pleadings
— as he should — and read it as a claim

1771.text:
for equitable compensation. The plaintiff
succeeded: an injunction was granted and equitable

1779.text:
compensation of just under $50,000 and costs
were awarded. Notably, the compensation was

1786.text:
expressed to be ‘for the damage she has
sustained in the form of significant embarrassment,

1792.text:
anxiety and distress’. He pushed the common
law.

1798.text:
In the report, Serious Invasions of Privacy
in the Digital Era, which was completed in

1803.text:
June last year, a chapter was dedicated to
the equitable action for breach of confidence,

1810.text:
and we recommended as follows: If a statutory
cause of action for serious invasion of privacy

1818.text:
is not enacted, and as an aside I say that
was our principle task - to draft such a course

1824.text:
of action. But if such a course of action
is not enacted, appropriate federal, state,

1830.text:
and territory legislation should be amended
to provide that, in an action for breach of

1835.text:
confidence that concerns a serious invasion
of privacy by the misuse, publication or disclosure

1841.text:
of private information, the court may award
compensation for the plaintiff’s emotional

1848.text:
distress.
We went with a legislative recommendation,

1851.text:
but recognised the clear trajectory of the
common law in that direction. In reading Justice

1858.text:
Mitchell’s decision I was greatly heartened
as the learned judge’s conclusions were

1863.text:
entirely consistent with the analysis that
we had made in that report. Indeed, I wrote

1870.text:
to him to this effect. As we hadn’t seen
our report noted in a footnote, I was curious.

1879.text:
I wrote and I asked, I said and he responded:
‘I was aware of the ALRC report and found

1886.text:
that it provided invaluable background reading
when I was preparing my reasons for decision

1891.text:
— a well researched and insightful analysis
of the issues.’ It’s a good illustration

1898.text:
of the impact of our work—a pebble in a
pond.

1903.text:
As Mr Kirby remarked, ‘The process of implementation,
like the ways of God, can be mysterious and

1917.text:
The process of the ALRC has both an immediate,
and a long-lasting impact — other ripples

1925.text:
in the pond. The success of the consultation
process is that it is personal. Commissioners

1932.text:
personally lead the consultations with a wide
range of stakeholders in each inquiry. Respectful

1938.text:
relationships are established and built through
the 12 months or so of each one and often

1944.text:
continuing from inquiry to inquiry.
Building relationships is one way in which

1951.text:
the reputation for independence is nurtured
and protected. You have to have the confidence

1957.text:
of stakeholders that their opinions carry
weight, that they will be listened to and

1962.text:
evaluated respectfully — with the outcomes
not determined in advance. Our mantra is - we

1970.text:
‘start with questions, never answers’,
in opening the conversation with those we

1975.text:
wish to embrace in any new inquiry.
Respectful relationships with stakeholders,

1982.text:
and with government, across the spectrum of
interests in any inquiry, enables the ripple

1987.text:
of effect to continue over many years. Relationships
are built not just with stakeholders, but

1994.text:
also with other law reformers. Many come to
visit, to learn by watching and being mentored

2000.text:
in our processes — like our colleagues from
Samoa and the Solomon Islands. On occasion

2007.text:
we are enlisted to provide hands-on training,
as for example in Papua New Guinea and Botswana

2012.text:
in both cases led by my predecessor, Emeritus
Professor David Weisbrot. We have hosted visits

2018.text:
at the ALRC, like those from Vietnam, Thailand
and China, wanting to know about our processes

2025.text:
and practices. Last week we were visited by
members of the Korean Crime Commission — South

2031.text:
Korean — who were seeking to use our experiences
for their own review of laws to make them

2036.text:
more robust against corruption.
In a presentation at the Alberta Law Reform

2043.text:
Institute in June 2008, on ‘Law Reform—Past,
Present and Future’, Mr Kirby referred to

2049.text:
the camaraderie that developed among law reform
agencies, and how the downsizing or abolition

2055.text:
of one was ‘like a death in the family’,
reminding each other commission of their ‘vulnerability

2062.text:
and mortality’. Through the up hills and
down dales of our international and national

2068.text:
colleagues, and vicissitudes of our own mainly
in the downwards direction in terms of scale

2073.text:
and budget, we have just kept keeping on.
‘Keep Calm and Carry on’, together with

2078.text:
my family motto of ‘Fortitude’, are deployed
regularly. And periodically we are called

2084.text:
upon to defend our existence. As Mr Kirby
observed, wryly, ‘No one owes a law reform

2090.text:
agency a free lunch’.
And here is where having built good relationships

2096.text:
helps. In 2010 we were called into the trenches
- our budget was significantly reduced and

2102.text:
it prompted a Senate inquiry. The Committee
focused in particular on the role, governance

2110.text:
arrangements and statutory responsibilities
of the ALRC and ‘the adequacy of its staffing

2116.text:
and resources to meet its objectives’. In
my opening statement in giving evidence to

2121.text:
the Committee on the 11th of February 2011,
I drew upon analogy to convey the impact of

2127.text:
the budget cuts or ‘savings’ as they’re
known in government-speak: the image that

2134.text:
kept returning was that of the Black Knight
in the film, Monty Python and the Holy Grail.

2141.text:
After he lost one arm defending his turf he
said, ‘Tis but a scratch!’; after the

2146.text:
other one was lopped off, ‘Just a flesh
wound!’. After both his legs were also chopped

2151.text:
off he still managed to say, defiantly, ‘The
Black Knight Always triumphs!’. Ridiculous,

2157.text:
but fitting. The reduction in the budget to
the ALRC made us, at the time, feel like that

2163.text:
poor knight. It was an enduring image and
the senators of that committee reminded me

2168.text:
on subsequent occasions ‘Professor Croucher
I cannot get the Black Knight out of my head’.

2174.text:
But what was heartening through that process
was to see those who came to our defence,

2179.text:
in making submissions to the Senate inquiry.
Some were fellow law reform agencies: the

2184.text:
New South Wales Law Reform Commission the
oldest institutional law reform body in Australia

2189.text:
; the New Zealand Law Commission and the Northern
Territory Law Reform Committee. Many were

2194.text:
legal centres and NGOs, and representative
bodies, such as the Law Council of Australia.

2199.text:
Some were academics. The Federal Court also
leapt to our defence, as did the Office of

2204.text:
the Australian Information Commissioner and
the Australian Academy of Law. The relationships

2209.text:
we had built, and the reputation we had established,
supported our case and the conclusion of the

2216.text:
Committee of the importance of our work — and
our existence.

2222.text:
Ripple three — the flame of ideas
I would like to end this part of my ‘pebbles

2229.text:
in the pond’ re-imagining, with a rather
aspirational conclusion. While implementation

2235.text:
statistics tell one picture, these other lenses
of imagining give a wider and more enduring

2239.text:
sense of impact. In a collection of essays
published in 1983, Mr Kirby reflected that

2248.text:
‘the role of the ALRC in promoting community
debate and professional acceptance of the

2253.text:
needs of reform may be a more lasting and
pervasive contribution to law reform in Australia

2260.text:
than any particular project’. And in 2008,
twenty-five years later, he expressed this

2267.text:
as ‘the flame of ideas’ kept alight by
permanent law reform bodies.

2273.text:
The flame of law reform affirms a central
concept of the rule of law itself: legal renewal.

2280.text:
As I repeatedly saw in Cambodia in work I
did there for the United Nations, one of the

2284.text:
greatest causes of corruption in the world
is the absence of regular machinery to modernise

2289.text:
and change the law to accord with contemporary
values and needs. Where there is no law reform,

2296.text:
corruption grows up, because it may be the
only way of getting things done.

2303.text:
In helping to keep the flame of ideas alight
we have adopted new technologies to expand

2309.text:
our modes of communication and community reach.
When Kirby was Chairman, he used cassette

2314.text:
tapes to convey messages. We now use their
contemporary equivalent, ‘podcasts’. We

2319.text:
tweet. We offer ‘ePubs’. We publish all
our submissions on our website. We use wikis

2325.text:
— even using one to assist in building a
catalogue of encroaching laws through the

2331.text:
technique of crowd sourcing in the Freedoms
inquiry. We have more than 9,000 twitter followers

2338.text:
and this year we were selected as a finalist
in the Excellence in eGovernment awards — not

2343.text:
bad for a very small agency. We accompany
all our reports with a short précis version,

2350.text:
as a separate Summary Report, which has to
satisfy one simple principle, it has to fit

2356.text:
in a briefcase and be capable of being read
between Sydney and Canberra. Through a commitment

2364.text:
to, and practice of, accessibility, we help
to fan the flame.

2372.text:
Reimagining Part Two — A Mannered Dance
Here I want to turn the lens to the relationship

2378.text:
with government. Respectful relationships
involve communication with and remaining clearly

2384.text:
at arm’s length from government — including
being seen to be non-political/non-partisan.

2390.text:
A simple example is when I encountered a previous
Attorney-General at Canberra airport, I was

2397.text:
landing and he was going. He said. “Ros
I have two people I want you to put on the

2403.text:
Advisory Committee, I thanked the Attorney
politely, said I would welcome his suggestions,

2410.text:
but the appointment of the Committee was for
the ALRC - code: and not for him.

2416.text:
The fact of being seen to be non-political
was tested almost two decades ago in an event

2421.text:
that triggered another specific inquiry.
On 29th of September 1997, a major controversy

2429.text:
broke as to whether the Attorney-General Daryl
Williams had suppressed a submission from

2435.text:
the ALRC to a Parliamentary Committee regarding
the Howard government’s Wik amendments - its

2441.text:
‘10-Point-Plan’ to the Native Title Act.
The ALRC submission was highly critical of

2446.text:
the constitutional basis of the plan. Shadow
Attorney-General, Senator Bolkus, alleged

2454.text:
that the Attorney-General Daryl Williams had
sought to dissuade the ALRC from making a

2460.text:
submission. In a doorstop interview at Parliament
House Senator Nick Bolkus said: ‘It’s

2465.text:
quite apparent that the Federal Government
is now at war with one of the most senior

2469.text:
and respected of public servants in Australia,
Alan Rose.’ Rose, a former Secretary of

2475.text:
the Attorney-General’s Department, was then
President of the ALRC. Senator Bolkus managed

2481.text:
to have the matter referred to the Committee
of Privileges.

2487.text:
What led to it was a normal kind of form letter.
I get them in my in-tray almost daily, alerting

2496.text:
the ALRC to an inquiry on one thing or another.
There was one two days ago from the Secretary

2502.text:
of Legal and Constitutional Affairs references
committee regarding an enquiry the committee

2507.text:
is conducting into the payment of cash or
other inducements by the Commonwealth of Australia

2512.text:
in exchange for the turn back of asylum seeker
boats. We get those requests all the time.

2520.text:
Most of them we do not make submissions about.
In this case the ALRC did make a submission

2526.text:
it was sent to Senator Minchin, Parliamentary
Secretary to the Prime Minister, with a copy

2530.text:
to the Department of Prime Minister and Cabinet.
But no copy was provided to the Attorney-General.

2537.text:
The Attorney-General was, to coin a phrase,
‘not amused’. He wrote to the ALRC pointing

2543.text:
out that the ALRC’s functions under its
Acts, ‘were confined to matters referred

2547.text:
to it by the Attorney-General’, by him,
and that he should have been consulted before

2552.text:
providing comments to Government ‘on a matter
which is unrelated to any current Reference

2557.text:
on which the Commission is working’. Richard
Ackland got onto it. The Acting Deputy Secretary

2568.text:
wrote a letter to the Editor. Alan Moir did
a cartoon. The Acting Deputy Secretary had

2575.text:
written to the ALRC saying ‘do you have
a death wish’. The ALRC decided not to press

2584.text:
ahead, it was going to give evidence before
the committee but the nub of the disagreement

2588.text:
went to the ALRC’s independence. The Committee
concluded that the decision of the ALRC to

2596.text:
withdraw was not ‘induced’, ‘by force
or threat, or by other improper means’ and

2601.text:
there was there was no contempt was found.
But the Committee considered it was necessary

2606.text:
for the Legal and Constitutional Legislation
Committee to take a long hard look at the

2610.text:
powers and functions of the ALRC. It began
in 2003, but that particular inquiry petered

2616.text:
out.
Where independence is our guiding mantra,

2620.text:
the relationship with government is necessarily
a sensitive one for law reform bodies—as

2626.text:
this episode confirms. It is a mannered dance.
If you overreach it, and lose the confidence

2634.text:
of government as a result, then, as Michael
Tilbury observed, a law reform commissioner

2639.text:
of note, a law reform commission ‘is effectively
functionless for the period that government

2645.text:
is in power’. Ensuring there are ‘no surprises’
for the Attorney is a different concept entirely

2652.text:
from ‘taking direction’, which is anathema
to independence. Martin Partington, former

2658.text:
Law Commissioner and Special Consultant to
the Law Commission of England and Wales, observed,

2663.text:
independence ‘does not mean that law reform
bodies should work in isolation from government’.

2669.text:
Having a regular and respectful, informative
communication loop is good practice — and

2674.text:
eminently sensible policy.
While the ALRC does not have a formal protocol,

2681.text:
as they do in the UK, we maintain an active
communication loop both with the Attorney-General’s

2688.text:
Department and with the Attorney. Particularly
in the light of the Rose/Wik episode. And

2694.text:
we also restrict commentaries to matters that
the ALRC has worked upon over the years, not

2701.text:
to current references, but to matters we have
worked upon over the years.

2707.text:
We write regularly when there is an enquiry
that traverses matters upon which we have

2712.text:
made recommendations, we draw attention to
our work, we draw attention to differences

2717.text:
in our work for instance where a proposed
bill deviates from our recommendations for

2722.text:
the information of the committee that is considering
them. But we don't go further than that. For

2730.text:
instance in a recent submission to Bret Walker
who was then independent National Security

2736.text:
Information monitor, he was asking about certain
National Security proposed provisions, we

2745.text:
ended our observations, after drawing attention
to previous work: ‘However, the ALRC has

2751.text:
no ongoing involvement with the operation
of the particular Act. Therefore, we have

2755.text:
no comments to make on whether its provisions
remain necessary, have been effective or should

2759.text:
be amended in some way.’ Were we given a
law reform enquiry about those questions of

2766.text:
course we would. So we keep a very straight
bat.

2771.text:
In a presentation that Mr Kirby made in 2008
in Alberta, he said that one difficulty to

2778.text:
the job of law reform was law reformer was
being ‘constantly torn between getting too

2783.text:
close to politicians and the media, in order
to attract interest in, and action on their

2787.text:
proposals or keeping too great a distance,
in order to avoid seduction and so as to maintain

2794.text:
product differentiation in the creation of
reforming ideas’. It is a delicate line

2800.text:
but a vital one, a mannered dance. Distrust
is not helpful to independence.

2810.text:
The third of my sections on reimagining is
what I’ve called Mille Fleur

2815.text:
Reimagining Part three — Mille Fleurs
When I was reflecting upon how to mark the

2820.text:
ALRC’s 40th anniversary, I wanted to capture
what I describe as the ‘mille fleurs’

2826.text:
nature of the process. To explain, in another
chapter of my life I studied and played a

2832.text:
lot of early music, as a longtime member of
the Renaissance Players of the University

2836.text:
of Sydney. And I loved the tapestries of the
Middle Ages and Early Renaissance, typified

2843.text:
by the exquisite series housed in Paris at
the Musée de Cluny, ‘The Lady and the Unicorn’.

2850.text:
There is another at The Cloisters in New York,
‘The Hunt of the Unicorn’. A distinct

2855.text:
feature of these tapestries is the thousands
of tiny flowers and animals scattered all

2861.text:
through the design. So I imagine law reform
as like the mille fleurs of those wonderful

2867.text:
medieval tapestries. There are so many contributions
of so many people, each a flower in the large

2874.text:
design, but integral to its overall power
and beauty. I wanted to convey the nature

2880.text:
of law reform other than through the now 126
reports that mark its institutional chapters,

2886.text:
to reveal it as something far more organic
and rich - and peopled.

2892.text:
So we are creating a virtual interactive timeline
as an archive of the ALRC, to be launched

2899.text:
in October as we formally celebrate our 40th
birthday. It captures some of the mille fleurs

2904.text:
of our history and its beauty is that it is
not finite, like a book, but a living, growing

2911.text:
thing and infinitely extendable. It includes
recorded reflections and greetings — ‘voicecards’

2917.text:
— from past Commissioners through the decades.
I was struck in reading through some of Michael’s

2926.text:
contributions through the decades, his vast
library of speeches, that he had a sense of

2930.text:
the same thing, although perhaps not through
the eyes of an erstwhile medievalist. It was

2936.text:
in his speech at the 25th anniversary where
he focused on the people of the ALRC — from

2941.text:
the team he assembled to the Secretaries of
the Department. It’s full of names with

2946.text:
fond reflections. He remembers with particular
affection the ‘originals’ of the photograph

2951.text:
of which I referred earlier, which, in his
imagining, resembled a sextet — although

2956.text:
I have to say it’s a curiously constructed
one.

2961.text:
The violin — soaring temperamentally and
making an awful lot of noise — was Gareth

2965.text:
Evans. A soothing French horn was Gordon Hawkins,
Professor of Criminology, always dependable,

2972.text:
silent when the other noise was going on,
yet with important solo pieces of his own.

2978.text:
On the timpani was Alex Castles, doyen of
Australian legal history. One was never quite

2982.text:
sure what sound would come out. But the mercurial
harmonies were usually brilliant. The oboe

2988.text:
was John Cain, shortly to become Victorian
Premier. He was constantly demanding that

2992.text:
we get back to the main theme. As an oboist
myself, I recognise this quality and so on,

2998.text:
the analogy continues. Kirby added that the
Commission was fortunate in the staff assembled

3003.text:
in its first years, and fortunate in the Presidents
and Commissioners that came after him. Concluding

3008.text:
his musical metaphor, he said: A great orchestra
was summoned forth. Its symphony is still

3014.text:
heard in the land. It is unique. It is different.
It is still playing to packed houses. Perhaps

3019.text:
I should add - a tendency to indulge oneself
in the delightful use of metaphor is also

3025.text:
a prerequisite for the Presidency of the Commission.
Anyway just some concluding thoughts—the

3032.text:
ALRC in the 21st century.
Why did the early Commission work so well?

3038.text:
And what lessons does this tell us on how
to fare in the 21st century. Kirby reflected

3044.text:
wryly on this in his voicecard contribution
to our 40th anniversary timeline. Why did

3050.text:
the Commission work ‘like clockwork’?
It was because, he said, we had wonderful

3055.text:
employees, great Commissioners and, above
all, an outstanding Chairman. Kirby imbued

3062.text:
the ALRC with a great sense of collegiality
from the outset. It’s part of his enduring

3068.text:
‘legacy’ of leadership of the ALRC, our
‘generally democratic’ structure, with

3074.text:
the staff ‘at every level’ being regarded
‘as part of the ALRC team’. I refer to

3079.text:
the team of legal officers and staff at the
ALRC as like a team of ‘elite athletes’

3083.text:
and our process of writing to continue and
extend my fluvial metaphors as one involving

3089.text:
a pile of rough pebbles, tossed into a fast
flowing river. After a process of tumbling

3096.text:
in the stream — the process of reviewing,
criticising and editing our own and each other’s

3101.text:
work — a pile of uniformly smooth and shaped
pebbles emerge. The democratic nature of the

3107.text:
process is also reflected in the way we credit
participants. Have a look at any report and

3113.text:
see the list of those who participated. From
interns to Commissioners and to those who

3118.text:
made submissions — all are acknowledged
for their contributions to the work represented

3123.text:
in the report.
One of the aspects of the ALRC that is central

3128.text:
to its legitimacy and survival as an independent
and effective law reform body is that it is

3134.text:
generalist. Its only specialism, if I can
call it that, is in the process of law reform

3141.text:
itself. Not being allied, or seen to be allied,
with particular views on any given subject

3147.text:
is an expression, both in fact and perception,
of intellectual independence. This is another

3152.text:
aspect of being ‘nimble’, being able to
take on board inquiries across the vast range

3159.text:
of matters embraced by Commonwealth laws,
and to lead projects that involve the complex

3164.text:
federal interactions of Commonwealth, State
and Territory laws.

3170.text:
The generalist capacity has also taken the
ALRC way beyond projects that might be called

3175.text:
‘black letter’ law, and to undertake inquiries
of a broadly social justice kind. We bring

3181.text:
in expertise, as Kirby did right from the
start, in the way of Advisory Committees,

3186.text:
or consultants as he called them then. And
it has proved a most enduring, effective and

3191.text:
enriching aspect of the ALRC’s mode of law
reform processes. Whether it’s on Human

3197.text:
Genetics, Copyright, Disability, Evidence,
Client Legal Privilege, Secrecy provisions,

3203.text:
Family Violence — we can dance nimbly over
any inquiry that the Attorney-General and

3208.text:
government of the day may seek to give us,
and, if it comes to that, I daresay we could

3212.text:
do an inquiry on microsurgery.
The ALRC in the 21st century has as much of

3222.text:
a role now as it had at its birth. It has
earned the respect in which it is held, both

3228.text:
nationally and internationally. But it is
not something that I, or my successors, can

3233.text:
ever take for granted. We have a high reputation
to maintain. We have demonstrated our independence

3240.text:
and we must continue to demonstrate the right
to have it.

3245.text:
But there is a shadow.
We all have to be constantly vigilant against

3252.text:
the threat of the ALRC’s extinction. There
is a danger of disappearance, either in law

3257.text:
or in fact, that is always a shadow on the
horizon for institutional law reform bodies.

3263.text:
We are vulnerable. We are mortal. The Law
Reform Commission of Canada, for example,

3269.text:
was established as a federal body, like the
ALRC, in 1971. It disbanded in 1993, and its

3275.text:
successor, the Law Commission of Canada, although
created by statute in 1997, did not have its

3281.text:
funding renewed in 2006. Closer to home the
Western Australia’s Law Reform Commission

3287.text:
disappeared into that state’s Attorney-General’s
department in 2013. Just last year, in 2014,

3296.text:
the National Commission of Audit, initiated
by the Treasurer, included in its report a

3302.text:
list of ‘Principal bodies for rationalisation’
— a word that sends shivers down the spine

3309.text:
of law reformers world-wide. It included bodies
that were to be abolished, those to be merged

3316.text:
and those that were to be consolidated into
the departments. The ALRC appeared in that

3322.text:
last category. Nothing has happened—so far.
In 2011 Lord Justice Munby, then Chairman

3330.text:
of the Law Commission of England and Wales,
concluded his Denning lecture in words that

3336.text:
resonate in my own experiences at the ALRC.
This is more a ‘half-full’ ending.

3341.text:
‘Some of what I have said may have sounded
rather downbeat, even depressing. These things

3345.text:
need to be said, if only so that Government
may hear them. But I should not want you to

3349.text:
go away downhearted on our behalf. The Law
Commission has never been in finer shape.

3354.text:
The morale and enthusiasm of our staff ride
high. It is a privilege indeed to lead so

3360.text:
dedicated and committed a team. We have survived
the storm. The future holds great promise.’

3367.text:
It is a ‘half-full’ ending and it is one
that I will certainly take as the hallmark

3371.text:
of our 40th anniversary celebrations.
At the end of his autobiography, Michael Kirby—a

3378.text:
private life, Mr Kirby ends with a somewhat
J Alfred Prufrock lamentation, in a series

3384.text:
of observations prefaced with, ‘if only
...’. I pick one: ‘If only the inexorable

3391.text:
ticking of the clock could be stopped and
the beauty of the present could be kept forever’.

3398.text:
The clock cannot be stopped, nor even slowed
— although we did add a second recently

3402.text:
— but we of the Australian Law Reform Commission
can fill its seconds with a very busy present

3409.text:
tense, conversation after conversation, inquiry
after inquiry, report after report, honouring

3417.text:
and doing justice to Michael Kirby’s vision,
and to our statutory charter to ensure that

3422.text:
the law reform recommendations are consistent
with Australia’s international obligations

3427.text:
and ‘do not trespass unduly on personal
rights and liberties’ of its citizens. We

3433.text:
must continue to keep the flame alight.
Thank you Bee-Chen for giving me the honour

3440.text:
of being able tonight to present the Michael
Kirby the 9th Michael Kirby Lecture tonight.

3444.text:
Mr Kirby, I doff my cap to you and thank you
all.
